Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to utilize the swelling-induced deformations of soft mechanical structures to dynamically shape materials. Adaptive structures that can bend and fold in an origami-like manner provide advanced engineering opportunities for deployable structures, soft robotic arms, mechanical sensors, and rapid-prototyping of 3D elastomers. Swelling is a robust approach to structural change as it occurs naturally in humid environments, and can easily be adapted into industrial design. Studies conducted under this award will identify the materials-defined length scales that dictate the mechanical response of a swelling structure. The swelling-structure interactions will be coupled with appropriate materials to controllably morph structures into a desired shape. The incorporation of polymerizable swelling materials will allow these complex shapes to be permanently fixed, thereby controlling the morphology of structures across many length scales.

A successful study will have broad implications for hierarchical manufacturing. The knowledge gained from these efforts will further the fundamental mechanical understanding of transient swelling-induced deformations, while developing a methodology for the permanent morphing of three-dimensional soft structures. This research will support the involvement of a strong, creative Ph.D. candidate, as well as academically driven undergraduate researchers. In addition to impacting education at the university level, this project will develop an innovative program to introduce local high school students to mechanics-driven phenomena. The program will use high-speed photography to show students the world of fast-moving science, and use this technology to study Newton's laws of motion.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Fluid-structure interactions occur across many length scales within industrial and biological systems. At large scales, fluid flow and weight can deform a structure, and at small scales, surface forces can cause large changes to an object's shape. In addition to external forces, a fluid can be absorbed into a structure, like a dry sponge swelling with water, and cause an internal stress that changes the object's shape. If the structure is thin, even small amounts of swelling can result in significant deformations. In an industrial environment, these swelling-induced shape changes can be destructive, as these stresses can cause materials to fracture or delaminate, thereby hindering their functionality.  However, if we understand how the fluid, material, and geometry interact to deform an object during swelling, we may be able to utilize swelling as a means for controllably morphing and growing structures into desired shapes - this hypothesis formed the overarching goal of this award. 


Swelling is inherently a fluid-structure problem that couples chemistry and mechanics. The fundamental interplay between swelling and structure allows us to consider swelling as a means for the precise and permanent shaping of structures. If we understand how a material will deform when exposed to a given amount of solvent in a specific location, we can bend and fold soft materials into complex structures. On an industrial scale, the ability to produce a generic structure that can be morphed into a desired shape has important implications for hierarchical manufacturing. The advent of 3D printing, for example, has been an essential advance in additive, bottom-up manufacturing. Permanent swelling-induced deformations build upon the premise of rapid prototyping to generate soft, elastic three-dimensional structures. In order to realize this possibility, it is necessary to develop a fundamental understanding of how to locally bend and fold a structure via swelling, and how to switch from transient to permanent swelling-induced behavior. 


The results from this award include determining when swelling will bend a structure, identifying how wetting and structural instability govern the dynamics of swelling, and developing a process known as "residual swelling", where small amounts of fluid are placed within a material, enabling permanent, programmable shape changes. These results could bring new insights to the swelling and drying of many soft, porous, engineered materials, such as textile and paper, as well the study of swellable biological structures, such as hair, certain types of plants, and other soft tissues. Additionally, the results may provide design criteria for using structural instabilities and swelling to create "designer" materials that grow into desired shapes or change shape on command. This award supported the development of one Ph.D. student, one M.S. student, and one undergraduate student. Additionally, this award fostered two international collaborations at Sapienza Università di Roma, Italy and the University Pierre et Marie Curie, France. The results from this research to date have been disseminated in five peer-reviewed publications, seven conference proceedings, and eleven invited research seminars.
